quizzes.question: Is 3.14 an integer?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Integers[/h1]

The [b]integer [/b]type holds non-fractional numbers, which can be positive or negative. Examples of integers would include 42, -42, and similar numbers.
[note]The size of the integer type varies according to the architecture of the system on which the program runs, although 4 bytes is the minimum size in most modern system architectures.[/note]

quizzes.question: Fill in the blank to declare a variable var that contains only positive numbers.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Integers[/h1]

Use the [b]int [/b]keyword to define the integer data type.[code format="cpp"][b]int [/b]a = 42;[/code]
Several of the basic types, including integers, can be modified using one or more of these type [b]modifiers[/b]: 
[b]signed[/b]: A signed integer can hold both negative and positive numbers.
[b]unsigned[/b]: An unsigned integer can hold only positive values.
[b]short[/b]: Half of the default size.
[b]long[/b]: Twice the default size.

[b]For example:[/b][code format="cpp"][b]unsigned long [/b]int a;[/code]

quizzes.question: Can floating point types hold negative numbers?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Floating Point Numbers [/h1]

A [b]floating point[/b] type variable can hold a real number, such as 420.0, -3.33, or 0.03325. 
The words floating point refer to the fact that a varying number of digits can appear before and after the decimal point. You could say that the decimal has the ability to "[b]float[/b]". 

There are three different floating point data types: [b]float[/b], [b]double[/b], and [b]long double[/b].

In most modern architectures, a [b]float [/b]is 4 bytes, a [b]double [/b]is 8, and a [b]long double[/b] can be equivalent to a double (8 bytes), or 16 bytes.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="cpp" ][b]double [/b]temp = 4.21;[/code]
[note]Floating point data types are always [b]signed[/b], which means that they have the capability to hold both positive and negative values.[/note]
